did.abstract: Material from a family that homesteaded in Albany County, Wyoming, in the 1870s.

bioghist.head: History of the Harriman Daniel Richardson Family
bioghist.p: Harriman Daniel Richardson and his wife, Elizabeth Tamer Page Richardson, homesteaded on Horse Creek in Albany County, Wyoming, in 1874. The couple had three daughters: Lovisa (b. 1873), Beulah (b. 1875), and Lucia Submit (called “Mittie”) (b. 1877). The girls grew up herding sheep and doing ranch work alongside a series of hired men. Lovisa was blinded by an accident when she was about thirteen years old. Beulah was a mail carrier for the post office. H.D. Richardson died in 1910 and Elizabeth Richardson died in 1912. Although the estate was divided between the three sisters, it was Mittie who stayed on the home ranch.

Beulah Richardson married Elmer LaPash in 1896. Elmer LaPash was clerk of Albany County School District #11 near the town of Buford. Caira Mae Simpson (1841-1930) was a sister of Elizabeth Richardson. Caira Simpson and her husband, Jabez Simpson, homesteaded south of Laramie, Wyoming, at Red Buttes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The H.D. Richardson family papers contain letters written by family members and friends to Lucia (“Mittie”) Richardson. These include letters from former ranch hands with whom she continued to correspond. Also included are photographs of the family and legal documents concerning land and water rights. There are letters and a ledger concerning the administration of Albany County School District #11. There is also a diary of Caira Simpson (1908-1914). In addition there are family histories compiled and edited by Keith C. Yeager, Beulah Richardson’s grandson.
